prs.truncated_body:
EVM deployments were failing with nonce errors on certain networks (e.g. Mezo) due to forge sending transactions too quickly without waiting for confirmation between transactions.
Example error:
`server returned an error response: error code -32000: invalid nonce; got 3, expected 2: invalid sequence: invalid sequence`

Added --slow flag to forge script commands in both `deployEvm` and `upgrade

extract Mezo slow flag logic into dedicated function

prs.title: interop: Remove checkInterop from Block Building Path
prs.truncated_body:
Through recent transaction handling designs, we have decided that putting a blocking RPC call against every interop transaction during block building is inappropriate. For the following reasons:
- It costs excessive time during building
- Transactions are filtered at mempool ingress already
  - The only way a transaction would go from pass->fail in this time is if a remote reorg occurred on the

commits.message: Remove checkInterop from Block Building Path

prs.title: op-node: Delete safe head db when EL sync is triggered
prs.truncated_body:
**Description**

Delete safe head db when EL sync is triggered. A new event is added to signal the start of the EL sync since the driver state doesn't otherwise know about it (only when it starts inserting payloads).

The EL sync may progress the safe head without it being derived by the consensus layer, which makes the safe head database inaccurate. To avoid returning invalid data the existin

commits.message:
op-node: Delete safe head db when EL sync is triggered.

The EL sync may progress the safe head without it being derived by the consensus layer, which makes the safe head database inaccurate.
To avoid returning invalid data the existing database is removed and it will start building again from where the EL sync completes.

prs.title: op-dispute-mon: Consider block numbers above MaxInt64 as always invalid

Updates dispute-mon to skip requesting output roots from op-node when the block number doesn't fit in an int64. These are obviously invalid because block numbers don't actually go that high (they're int64 in a bunch of places in execution clients).

Doesn't apply to fetching the super root since that's done by timestamp which is a uint64.

**Tests**

Updated unit test.

prs.title: Refactor and optimise commit interrupt
prs.truncated_body:
# Description

Currently, in bor, we use an interrupt context to notify the miner and EVM modules to stop block building when we hit the 2s mark to prevent delayed block announcement. While the check is pretty trivial, we do it before running every OPCODE which can lead to it using good chunk of CPU when processing transactions. An internal benchmark revealed that it used around 40% of CPU (out

commits.message: core, miner, common: use atomic variable to look for commit interrupt instead of channel every iteration
miner: simplify storing interrupt flag to avoid race conditions
core, miner: check for context.Done to prevent read calls from failing
remove global variable for commit interrupt

prs.title: Fix flake in TestNotifierReSubscribeAtPrefChange
prs.truncated_body:
## Why this should be merged

Fixes the flake in TestNotifierReSubscribeAtPrefChange

## How this works

The subscriber notifies the test to cancel the context via closing the signal channel, which in turn makes the test to call CheckForEvent on the notification forwarder.

However, the test goroutine proceeds to send a message down to the messages channel right after. The subscription fun

commits.message:
Fix flake in TestNotifierReSubscribeAtPrefChange

The subscriber notifies the test to cancel the context via closing the signal channel,
which in turn makes the test to call CheckForEvent on the notification forwarder.

However, the test goroutine proceeds to send a message down to the messages channel right after.
The subscription function, however, doesn't prioritize exiting and may read the message which was intended
for the next iteration of the forwarder.

This commit simply forces the subscription function to return early in its first iteration and not proceed
to read the message.

Signed-off-by: Yacov Manevich <yacov.manevich@avalabs.org>

This commit removes the toEngine channel pattern from the VM and adds an additional API:

```
WaitForEvent(ctx context.Context)(Message, error)
```

Unlike the toEngine pattern which only notifies the consumer a single time until a block is built, successive ca

commits.message:
Use explicit subscriptions instead of toEngine channel

This commit removes the toEngine channel pattern from the VM and adds an additional API:

```
WaitForEvent(ctx context.Context)(Message, error)
```

Which returns when an event (pending transactions or state sync done Message) is sent by the VM.

Unlike the toEngine pattern which only notifies the consumer a single time until a block is built, successive calls to `WaitForEvent ` will return that transactions are pending as long as the mem-pool is not empty and a block can be built, otherwise the calls block.

Having a dedicated API allows consensus to obtain information about whether a block should be built on demand and therefore correlated to a specific round, while using the current toEngine pattern makes it impossible to correlate with a specific round, and this makes it impossible to incorporate with consensus.

The EVM checks if transactions are in the mempool or waits until they arrive.

Unit tests and e2e tests

No

prs.title: feat: add shard and realm to `Client`
prs.truncated_body:
**Description**:
This PR adds `shard` and `realm` values to the `Client` to allow for proper network address updates. Without these, the address book would update itself with default values for shard and realm (0), therefore rendering the `Client` useless if its communicating with a non-zero shard and/or realm network.

**Related issue(s)**:

Fixes #441 

**Checklist**

- [x] Documented (
